hints.content:
Acceleration is the change in an object's velocity $(\Delta\vec{v})$ divided by the change in time $(\Delta t)$.

$\vec{a}=\dfrac{\Delta\vec{v}}{\Delta t}$

In other words, acceleration tells us how rapidly an object's velocity is changing.

The hare speeds up with an acceleration of $4 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}^2}$, or equivalently, $4\frac{\frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}$.

This means his speed increases by $4 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}$ every $1\space\text{s}$.

Since he starts at rest $\left(0 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}\right)$, after $1\space\text{s}$ he'll be moving with a speed of  $4 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}$.

After another second, or $2\space\text{s}$ total, he'll be moving with a speed of $8 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}$.

After another second, or $3\space\text{s}$ total, he'll be moving with a speed of $12 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}$.

After another second, or $4\space\text{s}$ total, he'll be moving with a speed of $16 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}$.

After another second, or $5\space\text{s}$ total, he'll be moving with a speed of $20 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}$.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

question.content:
Brown hares are small, but they are fast! They can run with a speed of $20 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}} \left(45 \frac{\text{mi}}{\text{h}}\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

Not only can hares run with high speed, but they can accelerate quickly from rest.

If a hare begins at rest and begins running with an acceleration of $4 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}^2}$, how long will it take him to reach a speed of $20 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}$?

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] $\space\text{seconds}$

[[☃ explanation 1]]
